user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_connection_reply:
```c
static void
check_connection_reply (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;  /**< a short alias */

  mhd_assert (c->rp.props.set);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != r->total_size) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Non-empty response body is ignored and not used.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != (r->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Application defined \"Content-Length\" header violates"
                 "HTTP specification.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
#else
  (void) c; /* Mute compiler warning */
  (void) r; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. The function parameter 'connection' is not modified: it is only used to initialize local const pointer aliases (struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; and struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;). These initializations do not assign to or modify the parameter itself. All subsequent uses dereference the pointer to read fields (and to pass values to logging), which is permitted (the rule allows modifying the object pointed to, but not the pointer parameter). The (void) casts only silence unused-variable warnings and do not modify the parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments that violate or require investigation for Rule 17.8 in this function.
